title: Cobbler Bootstrap
description: Bootstrap cobbler project with documentation: VISION.md, ARCHITECTURE.md, and ROADMAP.yaml. These establish what cobbler is, how it is built, and the release schedule before any code is written.

title: Write VISION.md
description:
## Required Reading
- .claude/rules/vision-format.md (format rule)
- .claude/rules/documentation-standards.md (writing style)
- .claude/rules/promt.md (Cupboard/Table design brief)
- Bootstrap description in .claude/commands/bootstrap.md

## Files to Create
- docs/VISION.md

## Requirements

Write VISION.md per vision-format rule. Cobbler is a CLI tool that orchestrates AI coding agents to plan and execute software development work. It connects to a crumbs cupboard (work item storage) and coordinates agents to plan work, execute work (docs or code), and track progress.

Sections to write:
1. Executive Summary: cobbler orchestrates AI agents to do software dev work; it is not a task tracker, IDE plugin, or CI system
2. Introduction: context (AI agents need coordination), problem (manual agent orchestration is slow and error-prone), what cobbler does (connects to crumbs cupboard, plans work, executes via agents)
3. Why this project: fills the gap between task storage (crumbs) and agent execution; leverages existing cupboard interfaces
4. Planning and Implementation: success criteria (agents complete doc and code tasks autonomously), phases table, risks table
5. What This Is NOT: not a task tracker (use crumbs), not an IDE plugin, not a CI system, not autonomous (humans approve)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All required sections per vision-format present
- [ ] Style follows documentation-standards (active voice, no forbidden terms, royal we)
- [ ] File saved as docs/VISION.md

title: Write ARCHITECTURE.md
description:
## Required Reading
- docs/VISION.md (written in prior issue)
- .claude/rules/architecture-format.md (format rule)
- .claude/rules/documentation-standards.md (writing style)
- .claude/rules/promt.md (Cupboard/Table design brief)
- Crumbs docs: /Users/petardjukic/WORKSPACE/crumbs/docs/ARCHITECTURE.md (cupboard/table interfaces)
- Crumbs PRDs: /Users/petardjukic/WORKSPACE/crumbs/docs/product-requirements/ (interface contracts)

## Files to Create
- docs/ARCHITECTURE.md

## Requirements

Write ARCHITECTURE.md per architecture-format rule. Describe how cobbler is built: components, interfaces, data flow, and design decisions.

Sections to write:
1. System Overview: cobbler connects to crumbs cupboard, coordinates AI agents to plan and execute work. Lifecycle of a work item through cobbler (ready → claimed → prompt built → agent executes → quality gate → closed). Coordination pattern: pull-based (cobbler queries cupboard for ready crumbs).
2. Main interfaces: Cupboard integration (import crumbs Go module, GetTable, Get/Set pattern), Agent interface (Run method, Tool interface), Executor interface (claim, execute, close loop).
3. System Components: CLI (cobra), Config (viper), Planner (analyze docs, propose crumbs), Executor (pick up and implement work), Agent (LLM abstraction, Claude impl), Prompt Builder (templates for doc/code tasks), Crumbs Client (thin wrapper around imported crumbs module).
4. Design Decisions: (a) import crumbs as Go module not CLI wrapper, (b) agent interface for provider abstraction, (c) prompt templates in internal/prompt not embedded, (d) Claude API first with interface for future providers.
5. Technology Choices: Go, cobra, viper, crumbs module, anthropic-sdk-go.
6. Project Structure: cmd/cobbler/, pkg/ (agent, planner, executor, crumbs), internal/ (prompt, config, claude).
7. Implementation Status: phase 1 focus is cobbler stitch --docs.

## Design Decisions
- Cupboard accessed via imported Go module (github.com/petar-djukic/crumbs)
- Agent interface allows swapping LLM providers; start with Claude via anthropic-sdk-go
- Prompt templates stored in internal/prompt/ as Go templates or embedded strings
- Executor handles both doc and code modes with shared claim/close logic

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All required sections per architecture-format present
- [ ] Components and interfaces described with enough detail for PRD authors
- [ ] Design decisions numbered with rationale
- [ ] Technology choices table present
- [ ] Project structure directory tree present
- [ ] Style follows documentation-standards
- [ ] File saved as docs/ARCHITECTURE.md

title: Write ROADMAP.yaml
description:
## Required Reading
- docs/VISION.md (written in prior issue)
- .claude/rules/use-case-format.md (release numbering scheme)

## Files to Create
- docs/ROADMAP.yaml

## Requirements

Write ROADMAP.yaml as a YAML file defining the release schedule and use case status for cobbler.

Releases:
- 00.0: Cross-release milestones (spans multiple releases)
- 01.0: Core stitch (docs) - cobbler stitch --docs working end-to-end
  - Use cases: cupboard connection, doc task execution, agent loop
- 02.0: Core stitch (code) - cobbler stitch --code working
  - Use cases: code task execution, quality gates (test, lint)
- 03.0: Planner - cobbler plan working
  - Use cases: project analysis, work proposal, crumb creation
- 04.0: Inspect and mend - cobbler inspect and cobbler mend
  - Use cases: project state display, test/lint fix loop
- 99.0: Unscheduled

Each release entry should include: focus description, list of use cases with status (planned/in-progress/done), and deliverables.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] YAML is valid and parseable
- [ ] All releases listed with focus, use cases, and deliverables
- [ ] Release numbering matches use-case-format convention (NN.N)
- [ ] File saved as docs/ROADMAP.yaml
